metadata./Keywords: PEEK; PEEK frame; PEEK implant; Scaffold; Bone defect; 3D planning; 3D printing; Allobone
metadata./Title: Use of scaffolds based on polyetheretherketone tubular implant in the treatment of a gunshot multifragmentary fracture of the proximal part of the shoulder with a bone defect: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background In connection with the war in Ukraine and the use of modern high-energy weapons by the enemy, 
the nature of  injuries have changed. These changes require improvement of approaches to the treatment of patients 
with gunshot and mine-explosive bone defects.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We present the case of treatment of a 28-year-old Ukranian man with a gunshot multifragmentary fracture of the proximal humerus with a bone defect using three-dimensional printing of a polyetheretherketone 
frame (scaffold) for alloplastic material. The analysis of this case expands the possibilities of using three-dimensional 
printing technologies of polyetheretherketone scaffolds in the treatment of significant bone defects.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Modern military trauma requires individualized treatment for each patient. The use of individual polyetheretherketone scaffolds in the treatment of a gunshot multifragmentary fracture with a bone defect has a positive 
clinical effect.
Keywords  PEEK, PEEK frame, PEEK implant, Scaffold, Bone defect, 3D planning, 3D printing, Allobone
Background
The majority of gunshot fractures of long bones are mul tifragmentary—this determines the complexity of recon structive operations. Patients with such fractures require multistage treatment using various bone–plastic surgical 
interventions and long-term rehabilitation periods.
Replacement of bone defects can be temporary, using 
spacer systems, and permanent, using autobone, allo bone, bioceramics, titanium augments, and frames based 
on the use of three-dimensional (3D) printing from inert 
metallic and nonmetallic (composite) materials. These 
frames (scaffolds) can serve as containers for auto- and 
alloplastic materials.
Technologies for preoperative 3D planning and 3D 
modeling of implants to replace bone defects are actively 
developing. As 7.1% of victims with gunshot wounds to 
the extremities are diagnosed with primary bone defects, *Correspondence:
Bazarov Murat
bazarovmurat71@gmail.com
1 Bogomolets National Medical University, Kiev, Ukraine
2 The Trauma Department of the Hospital m/u A2923, Kiev, Ukraine
3 National Military Medical Clinical Center, Kiev, Ukraine

Page 2 of 8 Buryanov et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:521 
which in 79.3% of victims exceed 3 cm [1], the use of 3D 
modeling becomes especially relevant.
Polyetheretherketone (PEEK) is a polyaromatic sem icrystalline thermoplastic polymer with mechanical 
properties favorable for biomedical applications. Poly etheretherketone forms: PEEK-LT1, PEEK-LT2, and 
PEEK-LT3 have already been applied in different surgical 
fields, including spine surgery, orthopedic surgery, max illo-facial surgery etc. [2, 3].
PEEK excels in fracture fixation owing to its radiolu cency [4]. Surgeons can see how the patient’s tissues react 
to this material, allowing doctors to monitor and predict 
the healing process. PEEK offers an optimal mix of flex ibility and stiffness, ensuring it does not get in the way of 
the body’s own healing processes. PEEK has an optimal 
combination of flexibility and stiffness. Another PEEK 
property that is of particular interest in orthopedics is its 
lightness. PEEK is much lighter than metal, which allows 
patients to manipulate joints and limbs with less effort 
than would be necessary with heavier metals.
In addition, based on the recommendations of 
ISO10993 “Evaluation of the biological effect of medical 
devices, ” tests were conducted for cytotoxicity, systemic 
acute toxicity, sensitization, and mutagenicity, which 
ultimately showed the biocompatibility of this material. 
Studies have shown that human osteoblasts are able to 
attach, grow, and multiply on this composite material.
The PEEK frame (scaffold) is a 3D-printed individual 
grid that serves as a container for auto- and alloplastic 
material.
Goal of the work
• Consider and analyze a clinical case of the treatment 
of a patient with gunshot multifragmentary fracture 
of the proximal humerus with the presence of a sig nificant bone defect
• To present the possibilities of using 3D printing of 
PEEK scaffolds for the treatment of bone defects.
Case presentation
The patient was a 28-year-old (1994) Ukranian man who 
was admitted for treatment to the Bogomolets national 
medical Clinic on 15 March 2022 with the diagnosis: 
“mine-explosive injury (14 March 2022). Fire shrapnel 
wound of the proximal part of the right shoulder. A gun shot multifragmentary fracture (stage III) of the proximal 
part of the shoulder with a bone defect (7 cm) and with 
the presence of foreign bodies in the projection of the 
fracture. Posttraumatic neuropathy of the median nerve 
with mild paresis of the flexors of the fingers. ”
Figures  1, 2, 3—computed tomography (CT) scan and 
X-ray of the shoulder—show:• Multifragmentary fracture of the shoulder with a 
bone defect (7 cm)
• Fixation of the head and diaphysis of the humerus 
with an external fixation device
Staged surgical interventions in the Bogomolets 
National Medical Clinic (Figs. 4 , 5)
Fig. 1 X-ray of the shoulder
Fig. 2 CT scan
Page 3 of 8

• 16 March 2022—secondary surgical wound debride ment. Sanitation with necrectomy of the gunshot 
wound and pulse lavage with decamethoxin solution. 
Drains were inserted and an aseptic bandage was 
applied.
• 18 March 2022—sanitation and thorough irrigation 
with antiseptic solutions of the wound on the right 
shoulder, partial suturing of the wound. Drains were 
inserted and an aseptic bandage was applied.
• 20 March 2022—sanitation and thorough irrigation 
with antiseptic solutions of the wound on the right 
shoulder. Drains were inserted and aseptic dressing 
was applied.
• 23 March 2022—sanitation and thorough irrigation 
with antiseptic solutions of the wound on the pos terior surface of the right shoulder. Aseptic dressing 
was applied.
• 25 March 2022—sanitation and thorough irrigation 
with antiseptic solutions of the wound on the poste rior surface of the right shoulder. Wound closed, rub ber drains inserted, and aseptic dressing applied.
• 11 April 2022—removal of the external fixation 
device and sutures removed. The operated limb was 
immobilized with a dezo bandage.The surgical intervention was determined according 
to the defect of the humerus (Figs.  1, 2, 3): implantation 
of an individual 3D printed PEEK frame (scaffold) with 
bone alloplasty at the place of the defect in the humerus 
with fixation of the fragments and PEEK scaffold with 
titanium locking compression plate (LCP) and screws 
with angular stability.
Preoperative examination included:
• Clinical examination
• CT scan and X-ray of the right shoulder and humerus
Preoperative control of analyses:
• Coagulogram performed on 20 April 2022
• General and biochemical blood analysis performed 
on 20 April 2022
• Urine analysis performed on 20 April 2022
Surgical intervention is planned after wound heal ing, removal of the external fixation device, reduction 
of local edema, and normalization of laboratory blood 
parameters.
Fig. 3 CT scan
Fig. 4 The appearance of the wound at staged surgical interventions 
(wound)
Page 4 of 8 Buryanov et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:521 
According to the diameter and shape of the proximal 
and distal fragments of the humerus, a frame with a 
cylindrical shape was designed—PEEK implant (scaf fold). This implant will serve as a frame for the allobone 
and perform an additional stabilizing function for the 
fragments.
A PEEK frame was printed after detailed preoperative 
3D planning (Fig. 6 ).
Surgical intervention (21 April 2024)
“Implantation of an individual 3D printed PEEK 
implant (scaffold) with bone alloplasty at the place 
of the defect in the humerus with fixation of the fragments and the PEEK implant with titanium 
LCP and screws with angular stability. ”
• An anterolateral (transdeltoid) incision was made.
• A multifragmentary fracture of the proximal part of 
the right shoulder and a bone defect (approximately 
6 cm) were visualized in the wound (Fig. 7).
• Bone fragments are cleaned of scar tissue. The PEEK 
frame was filled with corticospongy bone alloplasty 
(Fig. 8).
• A PEEK frame (scaffold) was implanted at the place 
of the defect in the humerus (Fig. 9).
• For metalosteosynthesis, we used an LCP and screws 
with angular stability (5screws distally, 6 screws 
proximally) (Fig. 10).
Fig. 5 The appearance of the wound at staged surgical interventions

• Postoperative X-ray control (Figs. 11, 12).
Postoperative examination included:
• Clinical examination
• CT scan and X-ray of the right shoulder and humerus 
(Figs. 11, 12, 13, 14)Postoperative control of analyses:
• Coagulogram performed on 22 April 2022
• General and biochemical blood analysis performed 
on 21 April 2022
• Urine analysis performed on 21 April 2022

At 6 weeks after surgery, the patient had a course of 
rehabilitation and physiotherapy treatment aimed at 
(Figs. 15, 16, 17):
– Increasing mobility in the joint
– Strengthening the muscles around the shoulder
– Developing movement coordination and increasing 
stability– Gradually increasing the volume and intensity of 
exercises
The course of physiotherapy consisted of ten sessions 
of phonophoresis.
The rehabilitation course consisted of ten classes with 
1 or 2 days rest between classes. After the course of reha bilitation treatment, the patient continued to perform 
exercises independently.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
In connection with the increase in the number of 
limb injuries with large bone defects, there is a need 
to find new or improve existing
sections.Methods:
methods of treatment 
of such conditions. We propose the use of individual 
3D printed PEEK scaffolds in combination with auto- 
or allografts as a new method of replacing large bone 
defects. Owing to 3D planning, the anatomy of the 
damaged bone fragment can be recreated as accurately 
as possible with an individual PEEK scaffold.
This material (PEEK) has an optimal combination of 
flexibility and stiffness, which is close to the parameters 
of autobone. Other advantages of this material are its 
radiolucency, low weight, and biocompatibility. How ever, the issue of further interaction of PEEK scaffolds 
with body tissues remains unresolved. That is why there 
is a need for further research and modifications of this 
material.
For positive
sections.Results:
results of such surgical interventions, 
we recommend following the general rules for replac ing the fixation method: elimination of inflamma tion, healing of gunshot wounds, healing of wounds 
after removal of the external fixation device, reduc tion of local edema, normalization of laboratory blood 
Fig. 15 Functional result
Fig. 16 Functional result
Fig. 17 Functional result
Page 8 of 8 Buryanov et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:521 
parameters, and absence of infectious agents in the 
fracture area during bacteriological examination.
For better biointegration of the PEEK scaffold, it is 
advisable to modernize this material with the possible 
use of orthobiological technologies.
Conclusion
1. Modern military trauma requires individualized 
treatment for each patient
2. Preoperative 3D modeling makes it possible to pro vide detailed preoperative planning, which reduces 
the risk of tactical and technical errors during sur gery and shortens the time of surgical intervention.
3. The use of individual PEEK scaffolds has a positive 
clinical effect. This method needs further research.
4. The individualized treatment of such and injury in 
this patients had a good functional result.
Abbreviations
PEEK  Polyetheretherketone
LCP  Locking compression plate
Acknowledgements
The authors would like to thank all the staff of the Bogomolets national 
medical Clinic (Kyiv, Ukraine) and would like to thank the staff of the trauma 
department of the hospital A2923 (Kyiv, Ukraine).
Author contributions
OB, AB, and OS carried out the surgical intervention; MB, DL, and OS took 
care of the patient; MB, OB, YY, YK, and IL analyzed and interpreted the results 
of the study; OB and MB contributed greatly to writing this article. The final 
manuscript was read and approved by all authors.
Funding
The authors declare that this study received no financial support.
Availability of data and materials
Additional data supporting the findings in this patient are available upon 
reasonable request.
Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
The patient consented to participate in the study and for publishing the 
results. The ethics committee approved this study. This project was reviewed 
and approved by the institutional review board at Bogomolets National Medical University.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of 
this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent 
is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
